title: Mayfair joins European hotspots as top holiday destination for wealthy

Mayfair has joined the likes of Monaco and Marbella as one of the top holiday resorts for wealthy tourists, according to a new report.
For years the London village was one of the most exclusive places to live, occupying the most expensive spot on the Monopoly board.
But after the war, many of the grand mansions were converted to offices and reflecting its diminishing influence, in recent times it even lost its spot on the famous board game.
Mayfair has joined the likes of Monaco and Marbella as one of the top holiday resorts for wealthy tourists, according to a new report
For years the London village was one of the most exclusive places to live, occupying the most expensive spot on the Monopoly board
Mayfair has undergone a rejuvenation and a recent report said it is again viewed by the wealthy as one of the premier luxury resort destinations
However, following its recent rejuvenation, a new report says it is again viewed by affluent foreigners as one of the premier luxury resort destinations - and it's not just visited and lived in by the wealthy middle-aged.

Paradise lost its tourist trade: How toxic politics have... 38 shares While almost 60 per cent of the 5,118 residents in Mayfair are now aged below 44, almost 45 per cent of those with the prestigious address are aged between 25-44.
Boasting an international affluence, there are residents from more than 42 nationalities, with 60 per cent of Mayfair's born overseas, up from 49 per cent back in 2001.
Playground of the young and wealthy: Almost 60 per cent of the 5,118 residents in Mayfair are now aged below 44, with almost 45 per cent of residents aged between 25-44
HOW MAYFAIR GOT ITS NAME Mayfair's name was derived from an annual fortnight-long fair that took place in the area from 1686 to 1764.
It used to be held on the site which is now Shepherd Market.
After complaints from residents, the fair was moved due to the feeling it attracted people from poorer areas of London.
Peter Wetherell, who runs the Wetherell estate agency, said: 'Mayfair has become a resort-village for affluent young 20 and 30-something residents from around the world.
'It is a global-oasis for young people, and a 'twin' of destinations like Monaco, St. Tropez and Miami, which are the other hubs where the world's wealthy elite choose to relax and enjoy their leisure time.'
Artist Charles Avalon has now created a special print of Mayfair in the lavish style of the vintage 1920s billboards for Pullman Editions, which is part of the Pullman Gallery.
The art deco poster is complete with the legendary Connaught Hotel and Scott's restaurant, where Charles Saatchi and Nigella Lawson were famously photographed.
Mayfair has been immortalised in the famous art-deco style tourist posters featuring Connaught Hotel and Scott's restaurant - where Charles Saatchi and Nigella Lawson were famously photographed
Artist Charles Avalon created a special print of Mayfair in the lavish style of the vintage 1920s billboards for Pullman Editions, which is part of the Pullman Gallery
Georgina Khachadourian, founding partner of Pullman Editions Ltd, said: 'Class, sophistication and finery are all synonymous with Mayfair, which is now the most exclusive address in Britain.
'Peter Wetherell's new 'Who Lives in Mayfair' report reveals that people from around the world view Mayfair as a luxury resort destination similar to Monaco or the Riviera.
'This is why we thought it would be fun to create a beautiful limited edition 1920s style travel poster to underline this new status.'
HOW MAYFAIR HOLDS ITS OWN AGAINST EUROPEAN WEALTHY HOTSPOTS Claridge's was founded in 1812 and is a well-known luxury venue in the Mayfair area
Claridge’s remains one of London’s finest hotels and watering holes for the wealthy.
The five-star property is situated at the corner of Brook Street and Davies Street and boasts long-standing connections with the royal family.
This has even led to it gaining the nickname 'annexe to Buckingham Palace.'
The Dorchester is a five-star hotel which has seen a number of high profile guests through its doors
There are always a line-up of flashy sports cars outside The Dorchester.
The opulent address has been a fixture in the area since 1931, and boasts unrivalled views of Hyde Park.
The hotel has long welcomed the rich and famous, with notable faces over the years including Elizabeth Taylor, Eisenhower and Tom Cruise.
Shirtmakers shop in Savile Row in London, showing a royal appointment plaque on wall
Savile Row is a Mayfair street which is known for bespoke tailoring.
It features a range of tailors which help tailor customers in suit styles ranging from traditional to modern to cutting edge.
Its services have been used by the likes of Napoleon III, Princes Charles and Jude Law.
Passion for fashion: Retail lovers can take advantage of the designer shops on Old Bond Street
If you are looking for designer shopping, look no further than Old Bond Street.
This southern section of Bond Street features renowned international fashion and jewellery designers such as Cartier, Gucci and Chanel.
The Royal Arcade, just off Old Bond Street, houses high-end retail outlets selling fine silverware, art, bespoke shoes and chocolate.
Mayfair has the Royal Academy of Arts which has many exhibitions and debates promoting the visual arts
Britain's first art school, the Royal Academy of Arts was founded in 1768 and exists as an independent, privately funded institution led by eminent artists and architects.
It uses exhibitions, debates and education to promote appreciation of the visual arts.
The Royal Academy's main event is its Summer Exhibition, which for more than two centuries has drawn from works entered by the public as well its Royal Academicians.
